bestBHT.bht: To Him alone belongs the glory and dominion, for it is God's might that perfects us. The doxology, though shorter here than in other places, is a similar expression of praise found in earlier verses. With confidence and gratitude, we give glory to God for the grace He bestows upon us and acknowledge His sovereign rule over all. May it be so, Amen.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: To Him—emphatic. To Him and Him alone: not to ourselves.
glory and—omitted in the oldest manuscripts and versions.
dominion—Greek, 'the might' shown in so 'perfecting' you.
Albert Barnes: To him be glory ... - See the notes at 1 Peter 4:11.
John Calvin: That he might add more confidence to the godly, he breaks out into thanksgiving.
Philip Schaff: To him be (or, is) the dominion unto the ages."
A doxology similar to that in chap. 1 Peter 4:11, but briefer.
The longer version of the A. V. is not sustained by sufficient evidence.
Archibald T. Robertson: To him (αυτω). To God (dative case). Note κρατος in the doxology as in 1 Timothy 6:16 and briefer than the doxology in 1 Peter 4:11, to Christ.
John Gill: glory is due to God for all the grace he bestows on men and to give it to him shows a sense of divine goodness, and a grateful heart"
to him very fitly is 'dominion' ascribed, whose kingdom rules over all, and who dispenses his grace, as well as his providential favours, in a sovereign way"
Amen, signifying that so the apostle prayed it might be, and believed it would be.

bhtAttempts.bht: To Him alone belongs the glory and dominion, for it is God's might that perfects us. The doxology, though shorter here than in other places, is a similar expression of praise found in earlier verses. With confidence and gratitude, we give glory to God for the grace He bestows upon us and acknowledge His sovereign rule over all. May it be so, Amen.

To Him alone, to God, be the might and perfecting shown in the grace He bestows on us. Glory, though omitted in some manuscripts, is due to God for all that He does, and to give Him glory shows a sense of divine goodness and a grateful heart. It is very fitting that dominion is ascribed to Him, whose kingdom rules over all and who dispenses His grace in a sovereign way. This is a doxology similar to one found earlier in 1 Peter, but shorter, and it is prayed with the belief that it will be so. Amen.

To Him alone, to God, be the might and perfecting shown in the grace He bestows on us. Glory, though omitted in some manuscripts, is due to God for all that He does, and to give Him glory shows a sense of divine goodness and a grateful heart. It is fitting that dominion is ascribed to Him, whose kingdom rules over all and who dispenses His grace in a sovereign way. This is a doxology similar to one found earlier in 1 Peter, but shorter, and it is prayed with the belief that it will be so.

To Him alone, to God, be the might and perfecting shown in the grace He bestows on us. To give Him glory is to acknowledge His divine goodness and express gratitude. It is fitting to ascribe dominion to Him, for His kingdom rules over all and He dispenses His grace in a sovereign way. This shorter doxology, similar to one found earlier in 1 Peter, is prayed in faith and belief, signified by the word Amen.

To Him and Him alone, not to ourselves, be the might and perfecting shown in the grace He bestows on us. Though omitted in some manuscripts, giving glory to God reflects a sense of divine goodness and a grateful heart. It is fitting to ascribe dominion to Him, whose kingdom rules over all and who dispenses His grace in a sovereign way. This shorter doxology, similar to one found earlier, is prayed with the belief that it will be so, signified by the word Amen.
